job_title: Registered Nurse in Las Vegas, NV
pros: I worked with an amazing team. It was a learning and fun environment in our unit. Having the support that I needed as I started my nursing career made a huge difference during my time as an RN at SVH. From our HUC all the way the leadership - we worked together during the most challenging times.
cons: Staffing was a challenge, we floated a lot.

job_title: UC/CNA in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Great staff and good benefits. Plenty of overtime
cons: Staffing ratios. Management switching three times in 2 years

review_title: Great people to work with, not so great conditions
job_title: RN I in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Staff and management are supportive on my floor, especially for new grads. Management will work around your education schedule and usually give you the schedule/time off you want. When things are stressful, your coworkers seem to be the only thing worth staying for honestly.
cons: Like most hospitals, administration can sometimes have unrealistic expectations for us to work in. -It's overwhelming for RNs to have 7:1 and CNAs to have 18:1, imagine being new and having that 3-4 days in a row -Charges are sometimes overseeing more than 1 unit when they're short, and the same charge will have 70+ patients to keep track of multiple days in a row that aren't even in the same hallway or floor -Vitals machines that are either missing or they don't have all functions on it (BP, HR, SpO2, temp) -Admins are asking us why patients are taking so long to discharge when they have 0 floor experience. Example, why would my patient's doctor discharge them when they can't breathe without portable oxygen that hasn't been delivered yet, can't walk without physical therapy being set up at home, etc. -If your RNs are saying a patient needs a sitter, BELIEVE them and send someone. You will have way less falls and assaults on hospital staff -Your pay for what you do is sad. You can look at other hospitals and get at least $10/hr for the same exact position and probably work under much safer conditions. I've heard of other nurses getting as little as a $0.03/hr annual raise, and most got under $1/hr.

job_title: NICU RN III in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Good coworkers but they are leaving in droves— and manager couldn’t care less
cons: Mandatory call shifts 2x/month New NICU manager here over a year now and actively avoids speaking to staff— not a single staff meeting Many significant changes being made by manager but without any support such as resources, education, staff meetings, etc. Small unit so low census and not very high acuity Everyone here seems miserable now

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Las Vegas, NM
pros: You will gain a lot of experience & learn who you can turn to for help
cons: 1:7 nurse-to-patient ratio. Mostly rude MDs, upper management doesn't care. The bottom line is money.

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Las Vegas, NV
pros: depends on who you work with, before all my floor nurses left, we were all very helpful and provided team work.
cons: HIGH turn over. everyone left. why? bad management and unsafe staffing. unsafe patient ratios. every unit went over ratio. BEWARE!!! the charge nurse on the top floor is always forced to charge TWO units when they’re short. that’s 70+ patients and 10+Nurses/CNAs to oversee. oh wait those nurses were also MOSTLY NEW GRADS!!! the director was barely ever present, she had her own issues. the leadership did not care about night shift and staffing, they just expected night shift to deal with it.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Las Vegas, NV
pros: By far the best leader that I have ever worked for. Nicole, director of 4N, is one of the most genuine humans I have ever met. She listens with intent, supports her staff, and truly makes people feel welcome. It's hard to be a new nurse and never once did her support and encouragement waiver. If it wasn't for my moving, I'd still be working for her.
cons: Being a new nurse is very difficult and 4N gets a lot of turnover, so staffing ratios are tough on some shifts.

job_title: Dietary Technician in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Great coworkers, somewhat flexible hours
cons: Bad management, you're treated as disposable. Lots of yelling and micromanagement. Expected to pick up the work of others. Hard labor for low pay.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Love it there no problems
cons: None I just love the staff

job_title: Registered Nurse in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Coworkers are fun and supportive
cons: Worked here for about a year and I have to say management and leadership can’t be any worse. Does not listen or care about their nurses and staff personal life. When short will add on shifts without your knowledge and are mandatory. When you speak out about an issue they give you zero solutions but instead guilt trip you and reprehend your thoughts.

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Columbia, SC

cons: Too much time on extra tasks and computer

job_title: Registered Nurse in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Charge nurses are amazing. Very supportive but always too busy doing audits.
cons: Lots of finger pointing instead of working together to solve problems. Patient care areas need more support. Leadership is pretentious and views employees as expendable. Rarely see the c-suite talking with employees on the units and if they do it’s just to point out what is wrong.

job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant CNA in Spring Valley, NV
pros: Clean hospital, great birthing center
cons:
Low pay no team work make cnas do everything and don’t acknowledge them
For hard work

job_title: ICU RN in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Co-workers. The majority are great. Some nurses have issues with belittling others during report time. (They are NOT very skilled themselves  so they lash out at others.)
cons:
IV pumps are broken. Equipment is hard to find and you need to search for it. There is not enough help which leads to nurses lifting fat patients all alone.  Visitors RUN WILD and lash out at nurses. Again, if there were just one more CNA, our "scores" would go up, which seems to be so all-important to get paid by medicare. One manager actually stopped ordering pens, pencils, post it notes and told her staff to buy their own...that's one of her cost-cutting measures. It's juvenile.
There are also too many visitors...they take over the patient rooms, demanding to sleep there as they are indigent or stuck in Las Vegas. They are rude and abusive and this is tolerated in the name of "customer service."  Patients get better with fewer visitors.  Nurses won't  go into rooms on a casual basis if they are constantly bombarded with "get me coffee, water, a "visitor meal," etc., and you end up treating them as if they are free guests in a hotel.
The doctors agree with us, but they are contracted. And they don't have to experience the  visitors all day long.  We didn't have COFFEE to give to the visitors for two months....trying to save a buck.
But the stock prices are very, very stable.

job_title: RN MSN in North Las Vegas, NV
pros: Great place to learn new skills as a nurse.
cons: Need organization. Pay needs to be adjusted.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Las Vegas, NV
pros: You can transfer to other hospitals .
cons: Too much work little pay, employee Unappreciation

job_title: Registered Nurse in Las Vegas, NV
pros:
Co staff is amazing
Facility is clean
cons:
Management not so good
Staffing problems every shift

review_title: Great Employer and Provider of Choice
job_title: Director in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Leadership and Teamwork is stellar. Family environment. Wonderful Physicians.
cons: No Cons to list. Great place to work.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Welcoming work environment; Modern facility; Supportive management team; Progressive
cons: None that I can think of

job_title: Registered Nurse in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Nice Co-workers. Great pay.
cons: They dump patients on you all at one. Triage and Charge nurse do not commicate when putting patients in rooms. No lunch nurse you just have to find time and punch out. Heart monitors is not where anyone can see it. If it's beeping no one cares. Had a patient on V tach no one noticed or cared they kept giving me other patients. Doctors are arragant and never put in their own orders. Treat nurse's like junk.  Can't find doctors with a critical patient they just tell you to give him fentynal drip and never put an order in.

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Some nurses do care about their patients.
cons:
Do NOT trust some of the 5 stars here. They are by the management.

RNs - No teamwork exists unless you are Filipino. Even if you are, it's literally like being in high school - bullying, stealing, gossiping, dramas, etc. No job satisfaction, no recognition, your voice will be ignored, and nurses work to death. Spring Valley made me to think about quitting nursing. I'm glad I left Spring Valley, not nursing.

CNAs - Most of the CNAs are always hiding somewhere. You will never find them. The only time they really check on their patients is at the end of the shift, so the patients are clean and look okay for the upcoming shift. I've floated to most floors, and only few CNAs were actually good.

Management - I just cannot believe that they were once nurses on the floors. They only care about the audits, numbers, and VIPs. That's all.

Patients - If you are not having a life-threatening emergency and don't need an ambulance, please go ahead and choose a different hospital for your safety.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Las Vegas, NV
pros: People are very friendly from the cleaning and kitchen staff to the nurses and managers to the office and administration. There are lots of educational opportunities, both advanced practice within your field and formal education such as assistance with bachelors to masters programs.
cons: As with most jobs these days, money is the bottom line and they constantly expect more and more from their employees with less and less to do the job effeciently.

job_title: House Supervisor in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Good location.  Lots of good people to work with.  Most areas displayed a large amount of teamwork.  Pay was satisfactory.
cons: Senior leadership seemed to  be out of touch with the day to day operations of the hospital.  They seemed to lack the necessary knowledge of how things worked and refused to listen to those who do.  All they cared about were the numbers.

review_title: Nurses taking the blame for poor management choices
job_title: RN in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Hard to realize something for this section.
cons: The new heart program and the surgeon in charge of it.

job_title: ER RN in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Some of the staff were nice.
cons: Pt safety is not a concern. You will take care of multiple ICU patients who board w/ you in the ER while being on a CODE team. There is no one to help watch your patients while you are in a code. You have multiple high acuity patients at a time with no help. If you have to give a critical result to a MD, you have to chase them down because they do not carry phones. This place is scary to work in. No one seems to care that their licenses or patients lives hang in the balance. This place should be shut down.

job_title: Staff RN in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Hiring process was quick and easy. Good teamwork and learning environment. Great training and orientation.
cons: They are about the budget. The will schedule the least nurses and CNAs possible due to costs. It unfortunately affects the nurse's stress levels and the patient's safety doing it that way.

review_title: Went from great to not so great...
